chapters.title: Chapter 7: Out of the Woods
chapters.info: Abell Cauthon, p. 77—Mat's father. His house was burned when the Trollocs attacked Emond's Field on Winternight. He has five children. See also Cauthon, Bodewhin; Cauthon, Eldrin; Cauthon, Matrim; Cauthon, Natti.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Ackley Farren, p. 421—Man who once got drunk and spent the night on the roof of the inn in Market Sheran.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Adan al'Caar, p. 18—Boy from Emond's Field that Mat fooled with a story about ghost dogs, shortly before releasing Master Luhhan's dogs covered with flour.

chapters.title: Chatper 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Adora Aybara; Perrin's sister. Her father and mother are Con Aybara and Joslyn Aybara. She has a brother, Paet, and a sister, Deselle.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Aemon al Caar al Thorin, p. 110—King of Manetheren during the last part of the Trolloc Wars, until the fall of his country. He was so fearless that the best compliment that could be delivered to anyone was to say that he had Aemon's heart. He was a Warder to his Queen, Eldrene. See also al Thorin al Toren, Caar; al Toren al Ban, Thorin; ay Ellan ay Carlan, Eldrene.

chapters.title: Chapter 45: What Follows in Shadow
chapters.info: Agelmar Jagad, p. 577—Lord of Fal Dara in Shienar. His head is shaved in the traditional Shienaran style, bare except for a topknot, and that completely white. He has brown eyes, and his face is as stony as Lan's.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Aginor, p. 12—One of the Forsaken, the thirteen Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to serving the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. His name is still used to frighten children.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Aldieb, p. 147—Moiraine's white mare. Her name means “West Wind” in the Old Tongue. See also Damodred, Moiraine.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Alene al'Vere is the second oldest of five daughters of Marin and Bran al'Vere of Emond's Field. See also al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Almen Bunt, p. 438—Man from the same village as Holdwin. He pretended to be fixing his cart while Holdwin was talking to a Fade, and later found he was looking for Mat and Rand. He later offered the two a ride, since he does not like Holdwin that much and would rather help the boys than the Darkfriend.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Alpert Mull, p. 416—Stolid man with a square face and square, worn hands. His cows have gone dry, his chickens have stopped laying eggs, and his pastures have gone barren. He wonders whether his land will even grow hay this year, much less a decent crop. He gave Rand and Mat a ride for a segment of their trip between Four Kings and Caemlyn. He gave them each scarves to keep the sun and dust off of them; they used to belong to his sons.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Alsbet Luhhan, p. 18—Wife of Haral, the blacksmith of Emond's Field. She is almost as strong as he is, and more ill-tempered. See also Luhhan, Haral.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Alsbet, p. 44—Queen of All in several of Thom Merrilin's stories. Her story predates the Age of Legends.

chapters.title: Chapter 8: A Place of Safety
chapters.info: Amyrlin Seat, p. 91 (97)—Leader of the Aes Sedai, their equivalent of a king or queen. Her authority is immense—rulers of all nations will obey a summons to the Amyrlin, even if they will spend the entire journey devising a plan to kill her while there. Moiraine says that Egwene may become the Amyrlin Seat some day if she works hard and studies hard enough.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Anla, p. 43—Character from The Thousand Tales of Anla, the Wise Counselor, one of Thom's stories.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Ara, p. 162—Dark-haired, slight man from Baerlon. He works at the Stag and Lion for Master Fitch.

chapters.title: Chapter 18: The Caemlyn Road
chapters.info: Arad, p. 228—Man from old Manetheren. According to Moiraine, his line is strong in the Two Rivers.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: Aram, p. 311—Grandson of Raen and Ila. He is of an age with Perrin. See also Ila; Raen.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Arent, p. 461—Elder of Stedding Shangtai, Ogier, and father of Loial. He insisted that Loial learn Treesinging. See also Halan; Loial.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Arin, p. 213—Assistant to the watchman at the Caemlyn Gate in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Artur Hawkwing, the name by which Artur Paendrag Tanreall was known during his conquest of the world. See Paendrag Tanreall, Artur.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Artur Paendrag Tanreall, p. 43—Hero of Legend who ruled all the lands from the Aiel Waste to the Aryth Ocean and beyond. He even sent troops across the Aryth Ocean, as well as to the lands beyond the Aiel Waste. His death set off the War of the Hundred Years. His sign was a golden hawk in flight; he was also known as Artur Hawkwing.

chapters.title: Chapter 6: The Westwood
chapters.info: Avendesora, p. 73—The Tree of Life of Legend. It leaves no seed, and is guarded by the Green Man, at least according to Legend. See also Avendoraldera.

chapters.title: Chapter 6: The Westwood
chapters.info: Avendoraldera, p. 73—Sapling cut from Avendesora, the Legendary Tree of Life. The tree was a gift from the Aiel to the people of Cairhien over a century ago. The tree was cut down by Laman Damodred, the King of Cairhien, twenty years ago. Laman's Sin, as this act is called, ended a century of peace with the Aiel and began the Aiel War. See also Avendesora; Damodred, Laman.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Ba'alzamon, p. 111—Ancient name from the Trolloc Tongue, believed to be the Trolloc name for the Dark One. It means “Heart of the Dark,” in the Old Tongue. Ba'alzamon claims to have sent the Trollocs during the Trolloc Wars for over three hundred years, told Artur Hawkwing to send armies across the Aryth Ocean, and told the same Hawkwing to refuse the Aes Sedai Healing that could have saved his life and proclaim with his last breath that Tar Valon must fall.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Bain, p. 416—Old man Mull knows. He let Mull have half a wagon for his own.

chapters.title: Chapter 42: Rememberance of Dreams
chapters.info: Balthamel, p. 539—One of the Forsaken, the thirteen Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. His name is still used to frighten children.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: Balwen Ironhand, p. 244—Nickname given to King Balwen of Aridhol. See Mayel, Balwen.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Bandry (Ban) Crawe is a young man from Emond's Field and the son of Samel. He is about ten months older than Rand.

chapters.title: Chapter 26: Whitebridge
chapters.info: Bartim, p. 325—Innkeeper of the Wayfarer's Rest, an inn where Thom, Mat, and Rand stop in Whitebridge. He complains of bad feet.

chapters.title: Chapter 35: Caemlyn
chapters.info: Basel Gill, p. 451—Fat, pink-faced innkeeper of The Queen's Blessing, an inn in Caemlyn. His graying hair is combed back over a bald spot it didn't quite cover.

chapters.title: Chapter 20: Dust on the Wind
chapters.info: Bayle Domon, p. 259—Stocky captain of the Spray, the boat Rand, Mat, and Thom leap on to in order to get from Aridhol to Whitebridge, and away from the Trollocs. He has long hair to his thick shoulders, a round face, and a beard that does not touch his mustache.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Bela, p. 2—Tam's work horse, a shaggy brown mare.

chapters.title: Chapter 7: Out of the Woods
chapters.info: Berin Thane, p. 77—Jon Thane's brother. His house was burned by Trollocs on Winternight. His house is across the street from Abell Cauthon's house. See also Cauthon, Abell; Thane, Jon; Thane, Kari; Thane, Lem.

chapters.title: Chapter 27: Shelter From the Storm
chapters.info: Berin, p. 339—Man whose retreat is the subject of a song the Tinkers sing, “Berin's Retreat.” It is known in Emond's Field as “The Wind From the North.”

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Berowyn al'Vere, is the oldest of the five daughters of Bran and Marin al'Vere. She is Egwene's oldest sister, and has been allowed to wear her hair in a braid, the Two Rivers symbol of adulthood for women, since she was sixteen years old. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Betrayer of Hope, p. x— See Ishamael.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Bili Congar is a man from Emond's Field. According to Egwene, he is always doing stupid things and always getting hurt. She has very little, if any, respect for him. He is of an age with Haral Luhhan, but he looks as though he is about ten years older due to his hollow cheeks and sunken eyes.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Bili al'Dai is a young man from Emond's Field. He is Master al'Dai's grandson. See also al'Dai, Bili.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Blaes of Matuchin, p. 205—Golden-haired hero of Legend. She is in one of Thom Merrilin's stories, “The Bargain of Rogosh Eagle Eye.”

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Bodewhin (Bode) Cauthonis a girl from Emond's Field. She is about one year younger than Egwene. She seems to enjoy telling on her brother, Mat, after he has gotten himself into mischief (which is quite often). See also Cauthon, Abell; Cauthon, Eldrin; Cauthon, Matrim; Cauthon, Natti.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Brandelwyn (Bran) al'Vereis the mayor of Emond's Field and innkeeper of the Winespring Inn. He is the father of five girls, including Egwene. He has a large girth, about double of anyone else, and a fringe of thinning gray hair. He is known around town as being very stubborn, and not someone to be trifled with. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Breyan Mandragoran, p. 595—Lain's wife. She was furious that her husband was not chosen as king of Malkier over her brother-in-law Akir; she dared her husband to march his men to Shayol Ghul itself. When they were defeated, she attempted to frame Akir, saying that if he had brought the rest of the men of Malkier, Shayol Ghul would have fallen. She then plotted with Cowin Fairheart to attempt to seize the throne of Malkier for her son, Isam. Breyan fled Malkier when it fell to the Shadow, disappeared with Isam into the Blight, and was never seen again. See also Mandragoran, Akir; Mandragoran, Isam; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Buad of Albhain, p. 205—Character from “The Last Ride of Buad of Albhain,” one of Thom's stories.

chapters.title: Chapter 21: Listen to the WindChapter 22: A Path ChosenChapter 23: Wolfbrother
chapters.info: Burn, p. 286—Wolf that Elyas knows. He is a grizzled fighter.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: Caar One-Hand, p. 244—Nickname given to Caar al Thorin al Toren, heir to the throne of Manetheren. See also Mordeth.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Caar al Thorin al Toren, p. 110—Aemon's father, Thorin's son. See also al Caar al Thorin, Aemon; al Toren al Ban, Thorin.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Calle Coplinis a young woman from Emond's Field. She has not been granted the privilege of wearing her hair in a braid, the symbol of womanhood in Emond's Field, even though she is well into her twenties. She enjoys flirting, and does not seem to be bothered by the fact that many girls as many as four years her junior are considered grown women while she is not.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Cenn Buie, the thatcher in Emond's Field. He is gnarled but spry, and speaks with a raspy voice. He sits on the Village Council, but is probably the most disagreeable member on it.

chapters.title: Chapter 15: Strangers and Friends
chapters.info: Ciel, p. 176—Waitress and kitchen assistant in the Stag and Lion in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Cilia Cole is a from Emond's Field. Egwene considers her a “ninny.” She likes to stare and make calf-eyes at Perrin; Egwene thinks Perrin at least ought to notice her attentions.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Cinda, p. 166—Servant in the kitchen of the Stag and Lion in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 15: Strangers and Friends
chapters.info: Cirri, p. 175—Cat in the Stag and Lion in Baerlon. She belongs to Sara, the cook. See also Sara.

chapters.title: Chapter 10: Leavetaking
chapters.info: Cloud, p. 121—Tall gray horse with a black mane and tail. Lan purchased him from Jon Thane, who used him for racing. Rand rode him out of Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Con Aybara, father of Perrin, Adora, Deselle, and Paetram and husband of Joslyn. See also Aybara, Adora; Aybara, Deselle; Aybara, Joslyn; Aybara, Paetram; Aybara, Perrin.

chapters.title: Chapter 24: Flight Down the Arinelle
chapters.info: Coramoor, p. 300—Man who, according to Sea Folk prophecy, will bring the Atha'an Miere out of the sea. See also Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Corin Ayellin is a slim woman from Emond's Field. She has a thick gray braid that hangs down as far as her hips. She bakes the best sweets in Emond's Field, possibly in the Two Rivers—Egwene asserts that her own mother's are better, but even her mother admits that Mistress Ayellin's are the best. See also Ayellin, Dav.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Cowin Fairheart, p. 596— See Gemallen, Cowin.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Cowin Gemallen, p. 596—Man who plotted with Breyan to seize the throne of Malkier for her son Isam. He was almost made King of Malkier himself—if two people had voted the other way on the council, he would have been. Unknown to everyone until shortly before the fall of Malkier, he was a Darkfriend. When they found out, many called for his head on a pike, but as he was so close to the king, he instead was allowed to duel with the king, and was slain by Akir. Also called Cowin Fairheart. See also Mandragoran, Akir; Mandragoran, Breyan; Mandragoran, Isam; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan; ti Mandragoran, Leanna.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Creator, p. xiii—Maker of the world, the True Source, everything in existence. At the moment of Creation, the Creator sealed the Dark One in a prison at Shayol Ghul to keep him from influencing the world. See also Dragon, The; Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Dag Coplin, p. 18—Boy from Emond's Field that Mat fooled with a story about ghost dogs, shortly before releasing Master Luhhan's dogs covered with flour. See also Coplin, Darl; Coplin, Ewal; Coplin, Hari.

chapters.title: Chapter 46: Fal Dara
chapters.info: Dai Shan, p. 583—Title used by those in the Borderlands for Lan, as well as others such as Agelmar. The title is that of the Diademed Battle Lords, the generals of the Borderlands. See also Jagad, Agelmar; Mandragoran, Akir; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 15: Strangers and Friends
chapters.info: Dain Bornhald, p. 188—Son of Geofram. He is a little too easily influenced, in his father's opinion. He was one of the men Mat got all muddy with his barrel stunt in Baerlon. See also Bornhald, Geofram.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Daise Congar, p. 7—Wit's wife. She is twice as wide as he is. She has a hard face, and not an ounce of fat on her. She controlls her husband much more than he controls her. See also Congar, Wit.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Dannil Lewin, a boy from Emond's Field. He is even skinnier than Rand, is a year older than him, and is described as having a thrusting nose.

chapters.title: Chapter 21: Listen to the WindChapter 22: A Path ChosenChapter 23: Wolfbrother
chapters.info: Dapple, p. 286—Wolf that Elyas knows. Her fur fades through a dozen shades of gray. She is the alpha female, the leader of her pack.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Dar, p. 213—Assistant to the watchman at the Caemlyn Gate in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Darith, p. 44—King in one of Thom's stories.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Dark One, p. 12—Name, used in every land, for Shai'tan. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 7: Out of the Woods
chapters.info: Darl Coplin, p. 82—Man from a farm near Emond's Field. He spent half the night demanding that Bran al'Vere send Moiraine and Lan away. He blamed them for bringing the Trollocs to Emond's Field. See also Coplin, Dag; Coplin, Ewal; Coplin, Hari.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Darling Sara, p. 390—Subject of a song Rand plays in Arien. He knows it as “Ferry O'er the River,” but the innkeeper there called it “Darling Sara.”

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Daughter-Heir (of Andor), p. 441—According to Andoran tradition, the first-born daughter of the Queen is her heir to the throne. The Daughter-Heir is traditionally sent to Tar Valon to receive training from the Aes Sedai, although until the current Daughter-Heir, Elayne, most have been too weak to get beyond novice training. See also Damodred, Tigraine; Trakand, Elayne.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Dav Ayellin is a boy from Emond's Field, of an age with Mat. He and Mat are friends, and like to get into mischief together. In fact, he and Mat seem to have a competition over who can get into the most trouble. See also Ayellin, Corin.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Davian, p. 171—False Dragon of old times. Ba'alzamon claims that he was used by Aes Sedai, just as all other false Dragons were. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 42: Rememberance of Dreams
chapters.info: Demandred, p. 539—One of the Forsaken, the thirteen Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. His name is still used to frighten children.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Deselle Aybara is Perrin's younger sister. See also Aybara, Adora; Aybara, Con; Aybara, Joslyn; Aybara, Paetram; Aybara, Perrin.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Doral Barran was the Wisdom of Emond's Field. She is the oldest woman in Emond's Field, possibly in the entire Two Rivers. She is white-haired and frail, though still clear-eyed and not stooped at all. Her last apprentice died of a mysterious illness that she could not cure. She mentored Nynaeve al'Meara, who recently replaced her as Wisdom. See also al'Meara, Nynaeve.

chapters.title: Chapter 3: The Peddler
chapters.info: Dragon Reborn, p. 30—According to the Prophecies of the Dragon, the man who will be Reborn at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world. He is the Rebirth of Lews Therin Telamon, the Dragon. It is said that he will save the world—and Break it again. See also Ablar, Logain; Amalasan, Guaire; Coramoor; Darksbane, Raolin; Davian; Dragon, The; He Who Comes With the Dawn; Stonebow, Yurian; Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 48: The Blight
chapters.info: Easar Togita, p. 607—King of Shienar. His capital is in Fal Moran.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Eazil Forney, p. 391—Farmer from near Arien. He was at the inn there, drank too much, and had to stay overnight. The innkeeper asked him to give the entertainment, Rand and Mat, a ride along the road for a ways.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Egwene al'Vere is a 17-year-old girl from Emond's Field. She is the daughter of Bran, the Mayor of Emond's Field, and his wife Marin. Egwene has four older sisters; Berowyn, Alene, Elisa, and Loise; and resents them at times for treating her as the baby of the family. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Elaida do Avriny a'Roihan, p. 440—Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah and advisor to Queen Morgase of Andor. She sometimes has the Foretelling. See also Trakand, Morgase.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Elam Dowtry is one of Mat's friends in Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Elan Morin Tedronai, p. x—Man who appears to Lews Therin Telamon shortly after he killed his entire family. He Healed Lews Therin from his madness, allowing him to finally realize what he had done. Elan Morin is now known as Ishamael, which means “Betrayer of Hope” in the Old Tongue. He claims to follow a “different power” now, that of the Dark One himself. He was once humbled by Lews Therin in the Hall of Servants, and defeated by him at the gates of Paaren Disen. However, Lews Therin fled and killed himself before Elan Morin could do with him as he had planned.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Elayne Trakand, p. 441—Daughter-Heir of Andor, daughter of Morgase and sister of Gawyn. She is quite pretty. She is preparing to leave for Tar Valon to undergo novice training, as all daughters-heir of Andor have done since the nation's founding. See also Damodred, Taringail; Trakand, Gawyn; Trakand, Morgase.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Eldrene ay Ellan ay Carlan, p. 110—Queen of Manetheren during the Trolloc Wars, wife of Aemon, her Warder. It was said that she was so beautiful flowers bloomed to make her smile. She was also called Ellisande, “Rose of the Sun” in the Old Tongue. See also al Caar al Thorin, Aemon.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Eldrin Cauthon is a girl from Emond's Field. She is about two years younger than Egwene. She seems to enjoy telling on her brother, Mat, after he has gotten himself into mischief (which is quite often). See also Cauthon, Abell; Cauthon, Bodewhin; Cauthon, Natti.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Elisa al'Vere is the third oldest of five daughters of Marin and Bran al'Vere of Emond's Field. She is one year older than Nynaeve. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Elmindreda (Min) Farshaw, p. 162—Young woman from Baerlon. She has short dark hair that she keeps like most boys her age do. She is slender, and barely taller than Moiraine. Her dark eyes are bigger than Egwene's. She dresses like most boys do, a habit she picked up from her hours in the mines with her father; her mother is dead. Min has a special ability, known to few; she can see images around people that predict their future. Moiraine calls them pieces of the Pattern. She sees a lot of things around Rand and his friends, but she claims that if she told Rand everything she saw about him, he would be as curly-haired as his “friend with the shoulders.”

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Else Grinwell, p. 388—Dark-haired, big-eyed, pretty daughter of the Grinwell farmers, the eldest of nine. She is nineteen, a year younger than Rand and Mat. See also Grinwell.

chapters.title: Chapter 21: Listen to the WindChapter 22: A Path ChosenChapter 23: Wolfbrother
chapters.info: Elyas Machera, p. 284—Man who lives in the woods. He has graying brown hair to his waist, held at the neck by a cord. He wears a thick beard across half his chest. He once was a Warder who taught Lan much about the Blight and his sword. He once had to kill other Warders to get away from the Red Ajah. He cannot channel, but he can talk to wolves, an ability which the Red Ajah wanted to do something about anyway. His eyes are yellow, and he can communicate with wolves by way of a kind of telepathy. He lives alone, except for his wolf friends, and never expected to find another who had the same ability—until he met Perrin. See also Aybara, Perrin.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Ewal Coplin, p. 39—Young man from the Two Rivers. He and the rest of his family used to make fun of Rand for his gray eyes, until Rand punched him in the nose. See also Coplin, Dag; Coplin, Darl; Coplin, Hari.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Eward Candwin, p. 109—Man from Emond's Field. He got a gash down his back when the Trollocs attacked, but was Healed by Moiraine.

chapters.title: Chapter 15: Strangers and Friends
chapters.info: Eward Congar, p. 187—Man from Emond's Field who always walks with his nose in the air. He once fell off the Wagon Bridge and had to come home all wet. That chilled him out for about a month, according to Mat.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Ewin Finngar is a boy from Emond's Field. He is about six years younger than Mat.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Farede, p. 658 (702)—Panarch of Tarabon near the end of the War of the Hundred Years. She was responsible for promulgating the calendar that now bears her name, which measures years of the New Era (NE), the first of which marked the (arbitrary) end of the War.

chapters.title: Chapter 8: A Place of Safety
chapters.info: Father of Lies, p. 96 (103)—One of the many euphemisms for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 20: Dust on the Wind
chapters.info: Floran Gelb, p. 259—Crewman on board Bayle Domon's vessel. Rand landed on top of him when he and his companions leaped onto the boat; Gelb was asleep on his watch. See also Domon, Bayle.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Gaidal Cain, p. 205—Hero of Legend. He appears in several of Thom's stories, including “Gaidal Cain's Sword.”

chapters.title: Chapter 40: The Web Tightens
chapters.info: Galadedrid (Galad) Damodred, p. 503—Handsomest man Rand has ever seen. He is tall and slender, and has dark hair and eyes. He is the son of Tigraine and Taringail Damodred, and the half-brother of Elayne and Gawyn". He always does the right thing, even if he should not. See also Damodred, Taringail; Damodred, Tigraine; Trakand, Elayne; Trakand, Gawyn.

chapters.title: Chapter 35: Caemlyn
chapters.info: Gareth Bryne, p. 455—Captain-General of the Queen's Guards in Caemlyn.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Gawyn Trakand, p. 441—Son of Queen Morgase and brother of Elayne. He will become First Prince of the Sword when his sister ascends to the Throne. See also Damodred, Taringail; Trakand, Elayne; Trakand, Morgase.

chapters.title: Chapter 28: Footprints in AirChapter 29: Eyes Without PityChapter 30: Children of Shadow
chapters.info: Geofram Bornhald, p. 377—Lord Captain of a band of the Children of the Light. He meets up with Perrin and Egwene in the abandoned stedding.

chapters.title: Chapter 41: Old Friends and New Threats
chapters.info: Gilda, p. 522—Serving maid in the Queen's Blessing in Caemlyn. She reports that there are Whitecloaks in the Common Room to Master Gill.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Grassburner, p. 661 (707)—Name, used especially by Aiel, for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Great Lord of the Dark, p. xii—Name used by Darkfriends to refer to Shai'tan, the Dark One; they claim that to use his true name would be blasphemy. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Great Lord of the Dark, p. 406—Name used by Darkfriends for the Dark One, claiming that to use his true name would be blasphemy. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Green Man, p. 43—Character in one of Thom's stories. According to Legend, he guards Avendesora, the Tree of Life, as well as the Eye of the World.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Guaire Amalasan, p. 171—False Dragon of old times. Ba'alzamon claims that he was used by Aes Sedai, just as all other false Dragons were. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Halan, p. 461—Elder of Stedding Shangtai, Ogier, father of Arent, and grandfather of Loial. See also Arent; Loial.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Haman, p. 496—An Ogier, one of the Elders in Stedding Shangtai. Loial has great respect for him.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Haral Luhhan is the Blacksmith of Emond's Field. His arms are as big as most men's legs, and his chest strains his shirt. He is the tallest man in the Two Rivers. Perrin Aybara is his apprentice. His wife, Alsbet, is almost as large as he is. He sits on the Village Council. See also Aybara, Perrin; Luhhan, Alsbet.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Hari Coplin, p. 108—Darl's brother. He also blames Moiraine for bringing the Trollocs to Emond's Field. See also Coplin, Dag; Coplin, Darl; Coplin, Ewal.

He-Who-Comes-With-the-Dawn.name: He Who Comes With the Dawn

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: He Who Comes With the Dawn, p. 316—According to the Aiel Prophecy, the man who will come to unite their people and lead them out of the Waste. See also Coramoor; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 27: Shelter From the Storm
chapters.info: Heartfang, p. 346—Name the wolves use for Ba'alzamon. See Ba'alzamon; Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Heartsbane, p. 601—Alternative name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Heran Adan, p. 167—Governor of Baerlon. He will not cooperate with the Children of the Light who are in the city.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Herot, p. 598—Hero of old. He has a crossing in Malkier named after him.

chapters.title: Chapter 21: Listen to the WindChapter 22: A Path ChosenChapter 23: Wolfbrother
chapters.info: Hopper, p. 286—Wolf that Elyas knows. He is an older wolf, but very smart. He is dedicated to Dapple; his mission in life is to see that what she wants is carried out.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Howal Gode, p. 400—Merchant from Whitebridge. He wears silk-lined velvet cloaks and velvet slippers. He drives two black coaches. He is also a Darkfriend.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Hu Barran, p. 21—Stablehand at the Winespring Inn in Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Hyam Kinch, p. 409—Farmer whose cart Rand and Mat ride after leaving The Queen's Man, an inn in a town along the Caemlyn road. He is leathery-faced and taciturn.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: Ila, p. 311—Raen's wife. She is a head taller than her husband. See also Aram; Raen.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Ilyena Therin Moerelle, p. ix—Wife of Lews Therin Telamon. She has blonde hair. She was called "Sunhair." She died along with her children when her insane husband killed them, and her. See also Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 46: Fal Dara
chapters.info: Ingtar Shinowa, p. 584—Soldier from Shienar. His hair is arranged in the Shienaran warrior style, shaved except for a topknot. He is one of the officers under Agelmar.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Isam Mandragoran, p. 596—Infant son of Lain and Breyan. His mother's attempt to seize the throne of Malkier for him ended in the fall of Malkier itself; Isam and Breyan disappeared into the Blight and were never heard from again. See also Mandragoran, Breyan; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Ishamael, p. 12—One of the Forsaken, the thirteen Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to serving the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. His name means "Betrayer of Hope" in the Old Tongue. He was called Elan Morin Tedronai in the Age of Legends, before he turned to the Shadow. His name is still used to frighten children. See also Betrayer of Hope;

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Jac al'Caar is a Shepherd from near Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Jaem, p. 43—Giant-slayer from one of Thom's stories. He is also featured in a song, “Jaem's Folly,” that is popular among Two Rivers folk.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Jaim, p. 396—Subject of a song Rand knows. It is called “Jolly Jaim” where Rand learned it, but in Four Kings it is known as “Rhea's Fling.”

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Jain Charin, p. 598—Makieri hero who captured Cowin Fairheart and brought him back to the Seven Towers for justice. He was already called Farstrider at that point. See also Farstrider, Jain.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Jain Farstrider is the main character in Egwene's favorite book, The Travels of Jain Farstrider. He has traveled all over the world, including the lands beyond the Aiel Waste and the Great Blight. He disappeared years ago and has not been heard from since.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Jak, p. 396—Bouncers at The Dancing Cartman. His arms are big enough to be legs.

chapters.title: Chapter 28: Footprints in AirChapter 29: Eyes Without PityChapter 30: Children of Shadow
chapters.info: Jaret Byar, p. 375—Tall Child of the Light. He has little in the way of human emotions, and thinks nothing of killing people. He hates no one; if he believes they should die, it is only because he thinks they should die, not because he hates them.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Jehaan, p. 598—Hero of old. He has a landmark in Malkier named after him: the Stair of Jehaan, the place where the last of the Malkieri gave their lives in a futile attempt to save their nation.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Jillie Lewin is a young woman from Emond's Field. She is a year younger than Elisa al'Vere, and wears her hair in a black braid that extends below her waist.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Jon Thane, p. 8—Miller of Emond's Field. His mill is actually out of town. He sits on the Village Council. See also Thane, Berin; Thane, Kari; Thane, Lem.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Joslyn Aybara is the mother of Perrin, Adora, Deselle, and Paetram and wife of Con. She is very pretty, in Egwene's view, who thinks her smile could make the Sun bide its head in defeat. See also Aybara, Adora; Aybara, Con; Aybara, Deselle; Aybara, Paetram; Aybara, Perrin.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Kari Thane, p. 153—One of Egwene's friends. Egwene asked Moiraine if she can channel when Moiraine said there was another woman in her village who could do so. She does not realize that the woman Moiraine was referring to was Nynaeve. See also Ayellan, Lara; Thane, Berin; Thane, Jon; Thane, Lem.

chapters.title: Chapter 6: The Westwood
chapters.info: Kari al'Thor, p. 68—Rand's mother. She died about fifteen years ago, when Rand was five. His only memory of her was that she had gentle hands and a soft voice. Tam met her when he left Emond's Field; they were married, and returned later with a child. See also al'Thor, Rand; al'Thor, Tamlin.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Karil, p. 44—Goodwife in one of Thom's stories. In this story, she cured her husband of snoring.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Kenley Ahan is a boy from Emond's Field in the Two Rivers. He is about two years older than Egwene.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: King Balwen Mayel, p. 244—King of Aridhol before its collapse. During his reign, a man named Mordeth came to be his advisor. Mordeth advised using the Shadow's tactics, its evil, against it; eventually this evil consumed the city, and only Mordeth survived. He was also known as Balwen Ironhand before Mordeth's arrival. See also Mordeth.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Kinslayer, p. xi—New name given to Lews Therin Telamon after he massacred his entire family and everyone he ever loved in his madness. See also Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: Lain Mandragoran, p. 595—Akir's brother, Lan's uncle. He was married to Breyan. His brother and he were as close as twins, and never let even Akir's becoming king get in the way. His wife, however, was jealous of Akir, and dared her husband to march his men all the way to Shayol Ghul itself, hoping to use the inevitable defeat as cause to pull Akir off the throne. Lain died in the Blasted Lands. See also Mandragoran, Breyan; Mandragoran, Isam; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 6: The Westwood
chapters.info: Laman Damodred, p. 70—King of Cairhien before and during the Aiel War, which ended about twenty years ago. He cut down Avendoraldera, the sapling from the Tree of Life, given to the people of Cairhein hundreds of years ago by the Aiel. This Sin, as it was called, precipitated the Aiel War and led to Laman's Death. See also Damodred, Moiraine.

chapters.title: Chapter 37: The Long ChaseChapter 38: RescueChapter 39: Weaving of the Web
chapters.info: Lamgwin Dorn, p. 490—Man Basel Gill hired to guard his door against anyone who would bring ill to his inn or its guests. He is bulky, and has heavy-lidded eyes. Despite his bulk, he moves like a cat. He thinks Morgase to be the greatest queen in the World.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Lanfear is one of the Forsaken; the thirteen Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. Her name is still used to frighten children into behaving as they should—it is said that she waits for children who steal.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Lara Ayellan, p. 153 (163)—One of Egwene's friends. Egwene asked Moiraine if she can channel when Moiraine said there was another woman in her village who could do so. She does not realize that the woman Moiraine was referring to was Nynaeve. See also Thane, Kari.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: Leafblighter, p. 316—Aiel name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Lem Thane is the son of Jon Thane, miller of Emond's Field. He is about eight months younger than Rand.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Lenn, p. 43—Man who flew to the moon in the belly of an eagle made of fire in one of Thom Merrilin's gleeman tales. The story precedes the Age of Legends. See also Salya.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Lews Therin Telamon, p. ix—The Dragon, Lord of the Morning, Kinslayer, Breaker of the World. He is a tall man just into his middle years. He was handsome once, but now he has more white hair than brown, and his face is lined from strain and worry. He has dark eyes. Known as the Dragon during the War of the Shadow. He killed his entire family in the madness that seized him after resealing the Dark One's prison. See also al'Thor, Rand; Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn; Kinslayer; Lord of the Morning; Moerelle, Ilyena Therin; Tamyrlin.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Lian, p. 205—Character in one of Thom's stories, “Lian's stand.”

chapters.title: Chapter 40: The Web Tightens
chapters.info: Lini Eltring, p. 501—Nurse to Elayne and Morgase during their respective childhoods.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Logain Ablar, p. 167—False Dragon from Ghealdan. News of his battles in Ghealdan reached Emond's Field with Padan Fain on Winternight—it was probably the last place in this part of the world to hear about it. He can channel the One Power, and has been able to defend himself against the Aes Sedai that are poised to capture and gentle him. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Loial, p. 461—Son of Arent son of Halan, an Ogier from Stedding Shangtai. He came to Caemlyn, and took up residence in the library of The Queen's Blessing. He is about ninety years old, which by Ogier standards is too young to leave the stedding alone, and ten years too young to address the Stump. See also Arent; Halan.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Loise al'Vere is one of five daughters of Marin and Bran al'Vere, the innkeepers of Emond's Field. She is six years older than their youngest daughter Egwene. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Marin.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Lord of the Dawn, p. xv—Alternative use of the title Lord of the Morning. See Dragon, The; Lord of the Morning.

chapters.title: Chapter 41: Old Friends and New Threats
chapters.info: Lord of the Grave, p. 530—Alternative name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Lord of the Morning, p. x—Title by which Lews Therin Telamon was known by during the Age of Legends and the War of Power. See also Dragon, The; Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Lothair Mantelar, p. 661 (707)—Author of The Way of the Light and founder of the Children of the Light.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Luc Mantear, p. 441—Son of the Queen of Andor before Morgase was queen. He disappeared into the Blight suddenly, and was never seen again. See also Damodred, Tigraine.

chapters.title: Chapter 43: Decisions and Apparitions
chapters.info: Machin Shin, p. 545—The Black Wind. It is a creature of the Ways, perhaps spawned from the taint, perhaps from something else. It wanders the Ways, consuming the souls of those it encounters. Those who make it out after being touched by Machin Shin are soulless, hollow shells—if they make it out at all.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Mandarb, p. 146—Lan's black stallion. His name means “Blade” in the Old Tongue. See also Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Mara, p. 43—Character from one of Thom Merrilin's stories, “Mara and the Three Foolish Kings.”

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Mari, p. 166—Servant in the kitchen of the Stag and Lion in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Marin al'Vere, p. 14—Bran's wife, Egwene's mother. She is slender, and keeps her hair in a thick, gray braid. See also al'Vere, Alene; al'Vere, Berowyn; al'Vere, Brandelwyn; al'Vere, Egwene; al'Vere, Elisa; al'Vere, Loise.

chapters.title: Chapter 40: The Web Tightens
chapters.info: Martyn Tallanvor, p. 505—Guardsman-lieutenant in the Queen's Guards of Andor.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: Mashadar, p. 244—The evil that consumed Aridhol, now called Shadar Logoth, during the Trolloc Wars.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Master Andra, p. 155—Name Lan uses in some cities, including Baerlon. See also Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Master Avin, p. 155—Gatekeeper of the south gate of Baerlon. He “forgot” that he let Alys, Andra, and their companions through the gate.

chapters.title: Chapter 28: Footprints in AirChapter 29: Eyes Without PityChapter 30: Children of Shadow
chapters.info: Master Aydaer, p. 374—Cabinetmaker of Emond's Field. He knows the value of good craftsmanship.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Master Cole is an old man from Emond's Field. He is as old as the Wisdom, perhaps even older. Despite this, he still has a full head of hair, though it's white now.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Master Fitch, p. 160—Innkeeper of the Stag and Lion, an inn in Baerlon. He has wispy hair that sticks out everywhere.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Master Grinwell, p. 388—Sturdy farmer with nine children. His farm is on the Caemlyn road. His eldest daughter, Else, is a year younger than Mat and Rand. See also Grinwell; Grinwell, Else.

chapters.title: Chapter 11: The Road to Taren Ferry
chapters.info: Master Hightower, p. 131—Man who operates the ferry at Taren Ferry.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Master Inlow, p. 425—Innkeeper at The Queen's Man, the inn where Rand takes ill. He was willing to treat Rand and crosserf("Mat") quite nicely, as long as Mat kept Rand out of the common room.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Master al'Dai is a lean old man from Emond's Field with wispy white hair. As old or older than Master Cole, he is unable to walk without the assistance of a cane. He is Bili al'Dai's grandfather. Despite his advanced years, his eyes remain clear and sharp, as does his mind. He is also quite quick with the shears, almost as fast as Tam al'Thor and faster than everyone else. See also al'Dai, Bili.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Materese, p. 44—The Healer, Mother of the Wondrous Ind in one of Thom's stories. Her story predates the Age of Legends.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Matrim (Mat) Cauthon, a boy from Emond's Field. He has brown eyes. Mat is known for his practical jokes and other mischief, often getting his best friends in trouble with him. He is good friends with Rand al'Thor and Perrin Aybara, though he seems to have a contest going with Dav Ayellin as to who can get the other into the most trouble. He has two younger sisters, Bodewhin and Eldrin. As a twenty year-old, Mat has grown to be one of the tallest men in the Two Rivers. He is still known for his practical jokes and other mischief; whenever something goes wrong in Emond's Field, Mat is the one everyone looks to first. See also al'Thor, Rand; Aybara, Perrin; Cauthon, Abell; Cauthon, Bodewhin; Cauthon, Eldrin; Cauthon, Natti.

chapters.title: Chapter 16: The Wisdom
chapters.info: Mavra Mallen, p. 200—Wisdom of Deven Ride. She came to Emond's Field to take care of things during Nynaeve absence.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Mistress Alys, p. 155—Name Moiraine uses in some cities, including Baerlon. See Damodred, Moiraine.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Mistress Aynora, p. 389—Woman with a rooster in a song Rand played at the Grinwell's house.

chapters.title: Chapter 7: Out of the Woods
chapters.info: Mistress Calder, p. 77—Owner of one of the houses that survived Winternight in Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Mistress Grinwell, p. 388—Yellow-haired mistress of the Grinwell farm. See also Grinwell; Grinwell, Else.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Mistress al'Donel, p. 10—Woman from Emond's Field. She demanded that Bran al'Vere fix the problem that no storks were nesting on the rooftops this spring. He honestly does not know what she would have him do.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Moiraine Damodred, p. 20—Guest in Emond's Field the day before Bel Tine. She has large dark eyes and keeps her dark hair in ringlets. She barely comes to Rand's chest. See also Alys; Mandragoran, Lan.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: Mordeth, p. 237—Sleek, overfed man with drooping eyelids. He is short and completely bald. Rand, Mat, and Perrin encountered him in Aridhol when they went off to see the city. In reality, Mordeth was the advisor to Balwen, the last king of Aridhol. He ordered the death of Caar, heir to the throne of Manetheren, when he came to Aridhol in an attempt to bring it back to the Second Covenant. His spirit has been trapped inside the walls of Aridhol ever since, and it is said that if he ever accompanies anyone to the city walls, he will be able to consume that person's soul and escape. See also Fain, Padan; Mashadar; Mayel, Balwen.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Mosk, p. 43—Giant who fought with a Lance of Fire that could reach around the world in one of Thom's stories. He fought with several people, including Alsbet, ruler off the world. The story of Mosk predates the Age of Legends.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Mother Brune, p. 425—Wisdom-equivalent in The Queen's Man, the inn where Rand takes ill.

chapters.title: Chapter 37: The Long ChaseChapter 38: RescueChapter 39: Weaving of the Web
chapters.info: Mother Grubb, p. 489—Woman in Caemlyn who sells herbs and poultices, births babies, tends the sick and tells fortunes. Rand considered asking for her services to help Mat.

chapters.title: Chapter 12: Across the TarenChapter 13: Choices
chapters.info: Mutch, p. 160—Worker at the Stag and Lion in Baerlon.

chapters.title: Chapter 5: Winternight
chapters.info: Narg, p. 63—Trolloc among those who attacked Tam and Rand on their farm. He stayed back and played dead when the other Trollocs left the farm—“Narg stay. Narg smart.” He speaks English, albeit poorly, and talked to Rand for a short time before Rand killed him with Tam's sword.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Natti Cauthon is a woman from Emond's Field and the mother of Mat. She is always calm and collected, which Egwene figures is necessary for someone with a son like Mat. She always seems to know about Mat's escapades; Mat is not sure how she always knows, but it is obvious to Egwene that his two younger sisters enjoy the role of tattletale. See also Cauthon, Abell; Cauthon, Bodewhin; Cauthon, Eldrin; Cauthon, Matrim.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Nynaeve al'Meara is a 24-year-old woman from Emond's Field. She has brown hair and eyes, and is quite slender. She studied under Doral Barran, the Wisdom of Emond's Field. After Mistress Barran's death, Nynaeve herself became the Wisdom. Her adult height is about as tall as Mat's shoulder. Many people still think Nynaeve is too young to be the Wisdom; however, mentioning this to her is a good way to get whacked by the stick she carries.

chapters.title: Chapter 5: Winternight
chapters.info: Oren Dautry, p. 57—Nearest neighbor to the al'Thor farm. He is a shameless borrower. Tam thinks he may have some livestock he is willing to part with.

chapters.title: Chapter 26: Whitebridge
chapters.info: Owyn Merrilin, p. 332—Thom's nephew, his brother's only son. Thom left his position as Court-bard in the Royal Court of Andor, where he was known from Tear to Maradon as one of the best bards, to help Owyn with some trouble he had with Aes Sedai. See also Merrilin, Thomdril.

chapters.title: Chapter 3: The Peddler
chapters.info: Padan Fain, p. 27—Pale skinny peddler with gangly arms and a huge beak of a nose that comes to Emond's Field about once a year. He always smiles and laughs as if he knows some joke no one else knows. He came just before Bel Tine to trade, and brought news of the war in Ghealdan against the false Dragon.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Paet al'Caar is a shepherd from near Emond's Field and the father of Wil. See also al'Caar, Wil.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Paetram (Paet) Aybara is Perrin's baby brother. See also Aybara, Adora; Aybara, Con; Aybara, Deselle; Aybara, Joslyn; Aybara, Perrin.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Paitr Conel, p. 419—Darkfriend that Mat and Rand encounter in Market Sheran.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Perrin Aybara is a boy of about 19 years of age from Emond's field. He is one of the tallest boys in Emond's Field, even taller than Rand, one of his two best friends (though since Rand is not yet finished growing, it is possible he will catch Perrin eventually). He is also good friends with Mat Cauthon, who often gets Perrin and Rand into trouble. He has curly hair, and is very stocky and generally big. He is very shy and laughs seldomly. His parents arranged to have him apprenticed to Haral Luhhan, the blacksmith of Emond's Field. Perrin has two younger sisters, Adora and Deselle, and one younger brother, Paetram. See also al'Thor, Rand; Aybara, Adora; Aybara, Con; Aybara, Deselle; Aybara, Joslyn; Aybara, Paetram; Cauthon, Matrim; Luhhan, Haral.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Prince of the Morning, p. xv—Title referring to the Dragon Reborn, in reference to the Rebirth of the Lord of the Morning, Lews Therin Telamon. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn; Lord of the Morning.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Promised One, p. xv—Name used in prophecies to refer to the Dragon Reborn, the man foretold to come at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world. See also Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 26: Whitebridge
chapters.info: Queen Morgase Trakand, p. 325—By the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Protector of the Realm, Defender of the People, High Seat of House Trakand. She is Elayne and Gawyn's mother. See also a'Roihan, Elaida do Avriny; Trakand, Elayne; Trakand, Gawyn.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: Raen, p. 310—Madhi (“Seeker”) of a group of Tinkers. He has gray hair, and is married to Ila. He is Aram's grandfather. Elyas, Perrin, and Egwene stay with them for a while. See also Aram; Ila.

chapters.title: Chapter 46: Fal Dara
chapters.info: Ragan, p. 583—Soldier from Shienar. He asked Lan, eagerly, if the Golden Crane would fly again.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Raimun Holdwin, p. 437—Man from a village near Caemlyn. He is a Darkfriend, and talked to a Myrddraal outside his inn.

chapters.title: Chapter 44: The Dark Along the Ways
chapters.info: Ramey, p. 555—Stablehand at The Queen's Blessing in Caemlyn.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Rand al'Thor is a shepherd from the Two Rivers. He is the tallest boy in Emond's Field. He has grey eyes and reddish hair, both of which are unheard of in the Two Rivers. His mother died when Rand was five; Egwene thinks he envies boys that have mothers. Rand is good friends with Mat Cauthon and Perrin Aybara. As a twenty year-old, Rand is about a head taller than Perrin, and taller than Mat as well. Rand and the Mayor's daughter, Egwene, have been all but Promised to each other since they were both young; this is often the subject of ridicule by Mat and Perrin. See also al'Thor, Kari; al'Thor, Tamlin; al'Vere, Egwene; Aybara, Perrin; Cauthon, Matrim.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Raolin Darksbane, p. 171—False Dragon of old times. Ba'alzamon claims that he was used by Aes Sedai, just as all other false Dragons were. He has been dead since before the Trolloc Wars, two thousand years ago. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 44: The Dark Along the Ways
chapters.info: Red, p. 555—Bay Rand borrows from Basel Gill. His hair is about the same color as Rand's own hair.

chapters.title: Chapter 19: Shadow's Waiting
chapters.info: Rhea, p. 244—Wife of Caar, son of Thorin, the king of Manetheren during the time Mordeth was in power in Aridhol. She killed her husband, and after he was buried killed herself upon his grave. See also al Thorin al Toren, Caar; Mordeth.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Rhea, p. 396—Subject of a song Rand knows. It is called “Jolly Jaim” where Rand learned it, but in Four Kings it is known as “Rhea's Fling.”

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Rogosh Eagle Eye, p. 204— See Rogosh of Talmour.

chapters.title: Chapter 17: Watchers and Hunters
chapters.info: Rogosh of Talmour, p. 204—Hero of Legend, a man famed at the court of the High King, Artur Paendrag Tanreall, feared on the slopes of Shayol Ghul. He was the greatest of all the Hunters for the Horn.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Rowan Hurn, p. 21—Member of the Village Council of Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Dark Waits
chapters.info: Rulan Allwine, p. 417—Innkeeper of the inn in Market Sheran, where Paitr Conel meets Rand and Mat.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Salya, p. 43—Daughter of Lenn in another of Thom Merrilin's gleeman tales. She walked among the stars in the story, which precedes the Age of Legends. See also Lenn.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Samel Crawe, p. 21—Member of the Village Council of Emond's Field. See also Crawe, Bandry.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Saml Hake, p. 394—Innkeeper of The Dancing Cartman in Four Kings. He is the first skinny innkeeper Rand had ever met, and the only one he did not trust.

chapters.title: Chapter 15: Strangers and Friends
chapters.info: Sara, p. 175—Cook in the Stag and Lion in Baerlon. She threatened to quit when Master Fitch relayed people's complaints about the rats her cat was apparently leaving all over the inn; in reality these rats had their backs broken by Ba'alzamon.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Scratch, p. 16—Yellow cat native to the Winespring Inn in Emond's Field. Her usual perch is next to the fire or on top of the bookcase.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Semirhage is one of the Forsaken, the thirteen powerful Aes Sedai who dedicated their lives to serving the Shadow during the War of the Shadow. Her name is still used to frighten children into behaving as they should. In her case, the threat is that she will come and get the child if he or she keeps lying.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Shadowman, p. 12—Boogeyman of the Wheel of Time.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Shai'tan, p. x—Source of all evil, antithesis of the Creator. He was imprisoned by the Creator at the moment of Creation at Shayol Ghul. This prison was bored into during the Age of Legends, which led to the War of the Shadow, the Time of Madness, the Breaking of the World, and the end of the Age of Legends. Since naming him by his true name brings ill fortune or disaster, many euphemisms exist, including Father of Lies, Grassburner, Heartsbane, Heartfang, Leafblighter, Lord of the Grave, Shepherd of the Night, Sightblinder, and Soulsbane. He is most commonly referred to as simply “The Dark One.” See also Ba'alzamon; Creator.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Shepherd of the Night, p. 12—Alternative name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 44: The Dark Along the Ways
chapters.info: Sheriam Bayanar, p. 555—Aes Sedai of the Blue Ajah. Moiraine tells Master Gill to contact her in Tar Valon if he got into any trouble for helping her.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Sightblinder, p. 464—Aiel name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: The Traveling People
chapters.info: Sightburner, p. 316—Aiel name for the Dark One. See Shai'tan.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Four Kings in Shadow
chapters.info: Strom, p. 396—Bouncers at The Dancing Cartman. His arms are big enough to be legs.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Susa, p. 43—Character who tamed Jain Farstrider in one of Thom's stories.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: Tad Barran, p. 21—Stablehand at the Winespring Inn in Emond's Field.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Tamlin (Tam) al'Thor, p. 2—Rand's father, a shepherd in the Two Rivers. He has a thick, broad chest and a broad face, gray hair with black streaks in it. His cheeks have been roughened by the sun. He is a solid man. Keeping his word is important to him. When Tam was young, he left the Two Rivers to see the outside world, something which is extremely rare in the Two Rivers. While there he acquired a sword, and married Kari, a woman from Caemlyn. Since Kari's death fifteen years ago, Tam has raised Rand himself. Since Tam has been alone and without a wife for so long, many women in Emond's Field have been trying to find a match for him recently. They've also started to think about who would be good for his son as well. See also al'Thor, Kari; al'Thor, Rand.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: Tamyrlin, p. xi—Title Lews Therin Telamon wore the ring of. It is likely this position was the predecessor of the modern Amyrlin Seat. See also Amyrlin Seat; Dragon, The; Lord of the Morning; Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Taringail Damodred, p. 441—Tigraine's husband, a prince of Cairhien, half-brother of King Laman. When Tigraine disappeared, he married Morgase Trakand, who had the best claim to the throne. He brought Cairhien into to the plotting surrounding the Succession. He had one child by Tigraine and two by Morgase: Galad, Gawyn, and Elayne. He did not really love either of his wives, his only goal being to see his son sit on the throne of Cairhien and his daughter sit on the throne of Andor. See also Damodred, Galadedrid; Damodred, Tigraine; Trakand, Elayne; Trakand, Gawyn; Trakand, Morgase.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Play for your Supper
chapters.info: Tarwin, p. 389—Hero of old and subject of many songs and tales. He has a pass, Tarwin's Gap, named after him between Shienar and what was once Malkier.

chapters.title: Prelude
chapters.info: The Dragon, p. xi—Name given to Lews Therin Telamon during the War of the Shadow. He did not like the name. The name is now associated with evil, since Lews Therin killed his entire family in his madness at the end of his life. It is said the Dragon will be Reborn at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world—and Break it again. See also Dragon Reborn; Telamon, Lews Therin.

chapters.title: Chapter 4: The Gleeman
chapters.info: Thomdril (Thom) Merrilin, p. 40—Gleeman who comes to Emond's Field on Winternight. He seems to have a distrust of Aes Sedai and their ways. He has white hair and mustaches, and wears a patched cloak. He was once a Court-bard. Fond of elaborate bows and flourishes. See also Merrilin, Owyn; Trakand, Morgase.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Thorin al Toren al Ban, p. 110—Father of Caar, grandfather of Aemon. See also al Caar al Thorin, Aemon; al Thorin al Toren, Caar.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Tiam of Gazar, p. 658 (702)—Person who proposed the Gazaran Calendar, which celebrated the alleged freedom from the Trolloc threat by recording Free Years (FY). This calendar was adopted due to the chaos the resulted during the Trolloc Wars and the resulting confusion as to which year it actually was under the Toman Calendar.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: The Last Village
chapters.info: Tigraine Damodred, p. 441—Daughter-Heir of Andor before Morgase became queen, sister of Luc Mantear. She disappeared before her mother died, and when she did there was no daughter-heir to take the throne, and the Succession began. There are some who believe she is still alive. See also Damodred, Galadedrid; Damodred, Taringail; Mantear, Luc.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Toma dur Ahmid, p. 658 (702)—Person who devised the Toman Calendar, which was adopted approximately two hundred years after the death of the last male Aes Sedai and continued until the Trolloc Wars. The Calendar recorded years After the Breaking, or AB.

chapters.title: Chapter 49: The Dark One Stirs
chapters.info: Treebrother, p. 622—What Loial calls the Green Man. See Green Man.

chapters.title: Chapter 50: Meetings at the EyeChapter 51: Against the ShadowChapter 52: There Is Neither Beginning Nor EndChapter 53: The Wheel TurnsGlossary
chapters.info: Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, p. 658 (702)—Sea Folk scholar and deviser of the Farede Calendar, which measured dates from the arbitrarily set end of the War of the Hundred Years as years of the New Era (NE). This calendar is currently in use.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Widow Aynal is a woman for which Widow Aynal's Meadow is named. No one remembers which Aynal widow it was actually named for; the meadow has been called that as long as anyone can remember.

chapters.title: Chapter 9: Tellings of the Wheel
chapters.info: Wil al'Caar, p. 113—Son of Paet from Emond's Field. He broke his leg during the Trolloc attack, and was Healed by Moiraine. See also al'Caar, Paet.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Wil al'Seen is a young man from a farm between Deven Ride and Emond's Field. He is a year older than Perrin. Egwene thinks his ears look funny, but many of the other girls in the village think Wil is quite pretty. As a teen, he always had girls staring at him and whispering behind his back. He courted every girl, and managed to convince all of them that he was just being polite to the others.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Web of the Pattern
chapters.info: Willim of Manaches, p. 460—Author of a book in Basel Gill's library, The Essays of Willim of Manaches.

chapters.title: Chapter 21: Listen to the WindChapter 22: A Path ChosenChapter 23: Wolfbrother
chapters.info: Wind, p. 286—Wolf that Elyas knows.

chapters.title: Chapter 1: An Empty Road
chapters.info: Wit Congar, p. 6—Man from Emond's Field. He and his family are reknowned troublemakers and complainers. He is scrawny, unlike his quite solid wife, Daise. See also Congar, Daise.

chapters.title: Chapter 14: The Stag and Lion
chapters.info: Yurian Stonebow, p. 171—False Dragon of old times. Ba'alzamon claims that he was used by Aes Sedai, just as all other false Dragons were. See also Dragon, The; Dragon Reborn.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: al'Akir Mandragoran, p. 595—Last crowned king of Malkier, Lan's father. He died, with his country, the day the Trollocs attacked Malkier. See also Gemallen, Cowin; Mandragoran, Breyan; Mandragoran, Isam; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan; ti Mandragoran, Leanna.

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Strangers
chapters.info: al'Lan Mandragoran, p. 20—Guest in Emond's Field the day before Bel Tine. He is quite tall, has long hair that is graying at the temples and is held from his face by a narrow leather headband. His face is all stony planes and angles, weathered but unlined. He is Moiraine's Warder. See also Andra; Damodred, Moiraine; Mandragoran, Akir; ti Mandragoran, Leanna.

chapters.title: Chapter 47: More Tales of the Wheel
chapters.info: el'Leanna ti Mandragoran, p. 596—Queen of Malkier before it was overrun. She was Akir's wife, and Lan's father. She died, with her husband and country, the day the Trollocs overran Malkier. See also Gemallen, Cowin; Mandragoran, Akir; Mandragoran, Breyan; Mandragoran, Isam; Mandragoran, Lain; Mandragoran, Lan.
